newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - March 17.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - March 17.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following business stories on Monday:

* Investment guru Warren Buffet told Berkshire Hathaway shareholders in his annual report he thought most stocks were overvalued, excluding his company's shares. The report also showed he has been buying stock in McDonald's.
* Luby's Cafeterias Chief Executive John Curtis Jr was found dead in a motel room on Thursday, and family and investigators have indicated he was having difficulties coping with job pressures.
* New England is once again experiencing an economic rebirth, based on high-technology ventures and services.
* The success of Data General's two key product lines, a server and a disk storage system, is behind the company's recent rebound.
* BellSouth to spend about $100 million to $150 million in a campaign to keep customers from switching to rival telephone companies.
* The broadcast industry does not see significant high definition programming on the air before 1999, forcing electronics makers to delay releasing the next generation of television sets.
* Programmers are becoming more successful in lobbying to be be carried by major cable operators.
* Scientists associated with Myriad Genetics have uncovered a genetic mutation found in people who have salt-sensitive hypertension.
* Publishers are increasingly aware that women are buying more books than men.
* Computer security professionals are in demand as companies rush to protect computer systems from intruders.
* Internet web site design is changing, including metaphors as well as images.
* Geocities and other providers of on-line tools claim people can set up their own pages on the web in 10 minutes.
* Ireland's St. Patrick goes on-line, with the full-text of his "Confessio" appearing on the World Wide Web.
* Japan's merchandise trade surplus rose 6.5 percent in February, as a weaker yen boosted exports.
* A hot spot to find information about Russia on the Internet is David Johnson's list of news, essays and commentary.
